title: Classes_assertHasMethods_Test.should_fail_if_no_methods_are_expected_and_methods_are_available fails with Java 19-ea
body:
**Describe the bug**

The test fails: https://github.com/vlsi/assertj-core/runs/6645816819, https://github.com/assertj/assertj-core/runs/6645470496?check_suite_focus=true#step:4:8585

See https://github.com/assertj/assertj-core/blob/09203199cf81e6482f8bab8d51f383ba1b207e92/src/test/java/org/assertj/core/internal/classes/Classes_assertHasMethods_Test.java#L62-L71

The failure looks like "failing test" even in the case I am sure I did not touch the code.

I would suggest:
a) Ignore failures in `java 19-ea` if you expect that "failures with 19-ea are allowable"
b) Fix the test
c) Fix the assert implementation. Does it really make sense to collect **private** methods from a class? What would be the purpose of such an assert? I can easily imagine that new private methods can be added to `java.lang.Object` in the future, so the very same `should_fail_if_no_methods_are_expected_and_methods_are_available` would start failing again. The worse is that every user of `assertHasMethods` would have to exclude all those "Object.wait0 private methods".  

In case you wonder, `wait0` is declared as following: https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/blob/73ba7fdce838ba8a2c227a972c176311e6cc0b41/src/java.base/share/classes/java/lang/Object.java#L377-L378


**Test case reproducing the bug**

Launch `Classes_assertHasMethods_Test.should_fail_if_no_methods_are_expected_and_methods_are_available` with `java 19-ea`.
